#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Ralph Rides the Wood
#Text=Under the Mountains
#Text=A long way now rode Ralph , and naught befell him but the fashion of the wood .

#Text=And as he rode , the heart within him was lightened that he had escaped from all the confusion and the lying of those aliens , who knew him not , nor his kindred , and yet would all use him each for his own ends : and withal he was glad that he was riding all alone upon his quest , but free , unwounded , and well weaponed .
#Text=The wood was not very thick whereas he rode , so that he could see the whereabouts of the sun , and rode east as far as he could judge it .

#Text=Some little victual he had with him , and he found woodland fruit ripening here and there , and eked out his bread therewith ; neither did water fail him , for he rode a good way up along a woodland stream that cleft the thicket , coming down as he deemed from the mountains , and thereby he made the more way : but at last he deemed that he must needs leave it , as it turned overmuch to the north .
#Text=The light was failing when he came into a woodlawn amidst of which was a pool of water , and all that day he had had no adventure with beast or man , since he had sundered from Agatha .
#Text=So he lay down and slept there with his naked sword by his side , and awoke not till the sun was high in the heavens next morning .
#Text=Then he arose at once and went on his way after he had washed him , and eaten a morsel .
#Text=After a little the thick of the wood gave out , and the land was no longer flat , as it had been , but was of dales and of hills , not blinded by trees .
#Text=In this land he saw much deer , as hart and wild swine ; and he happened also on a bear , who was about a honey tree , and had taken much comb from the wild bees .
#Text=On him Ralph drew his sword and drave him exceeding loth from his purchase , so that the knight dined off the bear 's thieving .
#Text=Another time he came across a bent where on the south side grew vines well fruited , and the grapes a-ripening ; and he ate well thereof before he went on his way .
#Text=Before nightfall he came on that same stream again , and it was now running straight from the east ; so he slept that night on the bank thereof .
#Text=On the morrow he rode up along it a great way , till again it seemed to be coming overmuch from the north ; and then he left it , and made on east as near as he could guess it by the sun .
#Text=Now he passed through thickets at whiles not very great , and betwixt them rode hilly land grassed mostly with long coarse grass , and with whin and thorn-trees scattered about .

#Text=Thence he saw again from time to time the huge wall of the mountains rising up into the air like a great black cloud that would swallow up the sky , and though the sight was terrible , yet it gladdened him , since he knew that he was on the right way .
#Text=So far he rode , going on the whole up-hill , till at last there was a great pine-wood before him , so that he could see no ending to it either north or south .

#Text=It was now late in the afternoon , and Ralph pondered whether he should abide the night where he was and sleep the night there , or whether he should press on in hope of winning to some clear place before dark .
#Text=So whereas he was in a place both rough and waterless , he deemed it better to go on , after he had rested his horse and let him bite the herbage a while .
#Text=Then he rode his ways , and entered the wood and made the most of the way .
#Text=CHAPTER 3
#Text=Ralph Meeteth With Another Adventure in the Wood Under the Mountain

#Text=Soon the wood grew very thick of pine-trees , though there was no undergrowth , so that when the sun sank it grew dark very speedily ; but he still rode on in the dusk , and there were but few wild things , and those mostly voiceless , in the wood , and it was without wind and very still .

#Text=Now he thought he heard the sound of a horse going behind him or on one side , and he wondered whether the chace were up , and hastened what he might , till at last it grew black night , and he was constrained to abide .

#Text=So he got off his horse , and leaned his back against a tree , and had the beast 's reins over his arm ; and now he listened again carefully , and was quite sure that he could hear the footsteps of some hard-footed beast going nowise far from him .
#Text=He laughed inwardly , and said to himself :
#Text=" If the chacer were to pass but three feet from my nose he should be none the wiser but if he hear me or my horse .

#Text= And therewith he cast a lap of his cloak over the horse 's head , lest he should whinny if he became aware of the other beast ; and so there he stood abiding , and the noise grew greater till he could hear clearly the horse-hoofs drawing nigh , till they came very nigh , and then stopped .
